Iconography/A Hopeful Truth will be included in Too Much Is Just Right: The Legacy of Pattern and Decoration exhibition at Asheville Art Museum (2 S Pack Square, Asheville, NC) February 2, 2023–May 29, 2023, guest curated by Marilyn Laufer & Tom Butler.

This exhibition “features more than 70 artworks in an array of media from both the original time frame of the Pattern and Decoration movement and contemporary artworks created between 1985 and the present. The artworks in this exhibition demonstrate the vibrant and varied approaches to pattern and decoration in art.

Artworks drawn from the Asheville Art Museum’s Collection join select major loans and feature Pattern and Decoration artists Valerie Jaudon, Joyce Kozloff, Robert Kushner, and Miriam Schapiro, as well as Anni Albers, Elizabeth Alexander, Sanford Biggers, Tawny Chatmon, Margaret Curtis, Mary Engel, Cathy Fussell, Shan Goshorn, Samantha Hennekke, John Himmelfarb, Anne Lemanski, Rashaad Newsome, Peter Olson, Don Reitz, Sarah Sense, Billie Ruth Sudduth, Mickalene Thomas, Shoku Teruyama, Anna Valdez, Kehinde Wiley, and more.”

#tawnychatmon

Iconography/A Hopeful Truth will be included in Too Much Is Just Right: The Legacy of Pattern and Decoration exhibition at Asheville Art Museum (2 S Pack Square, Asheville, NC) February 2, 2023–May 29, 2023, guest curated by Marilyn Laufer & Tom Butler.

Completing this piece was a tremendous undertaking. At one point, it required I work on it 12-16 hours per day; and if my guesstimation is correct, I laid 14,000-15,000 "tiles" in assembling their dresses. I made special little spaces for the kids to come in and watch movies, talk, spend time, and do their schoolwork in the studio with me to compensate for the time I usually spend with them outside of the studio. When I took a day off, I had to make up the time the following day to ensure I didn't fall behind. So many valuable lessons learned. I'm grateful and so eager to continue in this direction. 

About Iconography:
Iconography is a new and ongoing body of work influenced by Byzantine icons & religious iconography (with Klimt’s influence still being present in this piece). While in Venice during the Biennale, I stood again charmed by tilework, mosaics, and icons. An icon is a work typically of religious nature. These visual declarations were used to assist the observer in focusing on all things sacred and were viewed as literal prayers. My icons are not meant to be worshiped but regarded as important, precious, sacred, valuable, and an embodiment of my prayers. 

Slide 1- Iconography/A Hopeful Truth
24k gold leaf, 22k moon gold, acrylic paint, semi-precious stones & other mixed media on archival pigment print

Slide 2- detail shot

#tawnychatmon

I'm delighted to invite you to the opening of Afro-Futurist Manifesto: Blackness Reimagined on Thursday, March 16, 2023 between 6:00 - 8:00 p.m. where Pastoral Scenes/Monique in Pastiglia (flowers in her hair) will be on view alongsode incredible works by Larry Cook, Morel Doucet, Monica Ikegwu, M. Scott Johnson, Delita Martin, Arvie Smith, and Felandus Thames. 

“Galerie Myrtis
has partnered with the Reginald F.
Lewis Museum (RFLM) and the James E Lewis Museum of Art (JELMA) at Morgan State University to present the groundbreaking exhibition "Afro-Futurist
Manifesto: Blackness Reimagined" for the first time in the United States.“

Join us for the opening reception at the Reginald F. Lewis Museum (830 E Pratt St, Baltimore, MD) on
Thursday, March 16th from 6 - 8 PM (link to rsvp is in my bio) 

“The  award winning exhibition, curated by Galerie Myrtis' founding director, Myrtis Bedolla, premiered at the 59th Venice Biennale's "Personal Structures: Time, Space and Existence" satellite featuring the works of artists Tawny Chatmon, Larry Cook, Morel Doucet, Monica Ikegwu, M. Scott Johnson, Delita Martin, Arvie Smith, and Felandus Thames.” 

See you there! 

#tawnychatmon #reginaldlewismuseum #galeriemyrtis #delitamartin #larrycook #moreldoucet #monicaikegwu #mscottjohnson #arviesmith #felandusthames

✨in the news✨ swipe ✨
“The Afro-Futurist Manifesto: Blackness Reimagined” is featured in the Baltimore Banner article “The future of African American art finds a home in Maryland” written by Imani Spence. This periodical highlights how “The Afro-Futurist Manifesto” was able to travel to the US for the first time after it’s debut at the 59th Venice Biennale through a collaboration between, exhibition curator and founding director of Galerie Myrtis, Myrtis Bedolla and the Reginald F. Lewis Museum. Alongside Bedolla, featured artists Tawny Chatmon and Monica Ikegwu were interviewed on what inspired them to create works for the show.

“The Afro-Futurist Manifesto: Blackness Reimagined” is on view at the Reginald F. Lewis Museum through September 5th. For more information on the exhibition, go to www.lewismuseum.org!

Shared via @galeriemyrtis

*click the link in my bio to read the full article*

How did you know you were an artist?

“I guess when others gave me that title is when I realized that’s what I was, an artist. I have always been one, we are all born creators. 

The artist survives in some of us, and in others it lies dormant as we grow up. It’s still there though, just needs to be awakened. 

We’re all makers/creators/artists of some sort.” — Tawny Chatmon @tawnychatmon 

@artistsoncouches 

#tawnychatmon #artistsoncouches #artisttalk #conversationswithartists #meettheartist #artistlife #purposeofart #artistssupportartists #artlife #artistsoninstagram #onthecouch#artistsupportpost #artcommunity #artistcommunity #artistspotlight #artspotlight

✨I think I might let this photo live here on my Instagram✨

Check back 2 hours from now to see if it survived 😅

I took this photo (and a few others) for a feature on @artistsoncouches. They asked:

How did you know you were an artist?

My answer: I guess when others gave me that title is when I realized that’s what I was, an artist. I have always been one, we are all born creators. The artist survives in some of us, and in others it lies dormant as we grow up. It’s still there though, just needs to be awakened. We’re all makers/creators/artists of some sort.

—
How about you? How did you know?

⭐️Exhibition Announcement⭐️
Opening tonight! 

It is with profound joy that I announce a monumental collaborative exhibition with my kindred soul sister @fabiolajeanlouis . From the inception of this project to its breathtaking completion, I have been privileged to witness (and be a part of) the evolution of divine brilliance & vision. This exhibition also serves as a testament to the power of nurturing young talent as Fabiola worked with a group of incredibly gifted college students who lent their creativity to bring this exhibition to life during her residency at UCA. This has been a transformative and inspirational experience on many levels, and I am honored to be a part of this exhibition. 

🌟WATERS OF THE ABYSS: An Intersection of Spirit and Freedom

May 11 - May 31, 2023

Opening reception: Thursday, May 11, 2023 | 4-7 PM
Location: Baum Gallery at the University of Central Arkansas
McCastlain Hall (West Wing)
201 Donaghey Avenue, Conway, AR 72035

Very happy to share this beautiful clip from the series ‘Gold in Motion: Contemporary Artists on Klimt’, produced by @friezeofficial in collaboration with @halldeslumieres.

Repost from @friezeofficial
In the third and final video of the series ‘Gold in Motion: Contemporary Artists on Klimt’ artist Tawny Chatmon (@tawnychatmon) reflects on what it felt like to see Klimt’s work for the first time, what it means to adorn a body in gold and how she looks to reinterpret the museum experience for Black families.

The series, produced in collaboration with Hall des Lumières (@halldeslumieres), New York’s permanent digital art center, previously saw contemporary artists Emma Talbot and Osman Yousefzada talk about Klimt and their relationship with his work to celebrate the immersive and multi-sensory exhibition, Gustav Klimt: Gold in Motion, dedicated to the Viennese artist.” -Frieze⁠
⁠
Go to @halldeslumieres for GUSTAV KLIMT: GOLD IN MOTION 

—
Just a tiny note. Obviously everything I said can not be added in one clip so trimming occurs ☺️ just thought I’d mention that the end of the sentence mentioning my sitters most likely continued with “90% of the time, my sitters are my children, family members, nieces, nephews, Godchildren, etc.” thank you all for being such amazing subjects ❤️

#tawnychatmon

✨ I’m happy to announce that a limited edition print of "Let me go forward" will be available during a silent auction taking place June 25th from 5-8 pm at the Baltimore Museum of Art for a benefit supporting the BMA (@baltimoremuseumofart) and The Last Resort Artist Retreat (@thelastresortartistretreat ). The silent auction will feature works by myself, Derrick Adams, Jabari Jefferson, Jamaal Peterman, Murjoni Merriweather, and more. All auction proceeds will directly support TLRAR.  Click the links in my bio to learn more and to buy tickets to attend the gala and participate in the auction (online or in person). 

About the gala: 
"Join us in welcoming Asma Naeem, the BMA’s newly appointed Dorothy Wagner Wallis Director, for an art benefit supporting the Baltimore Museum of Art and The Last Resort Artist Retreat (TLRAR).

The highlight of the evening will be supporting brilliant artists with strong ties to the Baltimore region through a silent auction."

About the silent auction:

"Online bidding opens on Sunday, June 25, 2023. A link to participate in the silent auction will be emailed to all confirmed participants on the morning of June 25. To participate
in the auction, you must purchase an event ticket, available at artbma.org/auction.”

About The Last Resort Artist Retreat:

"The Last Resort Artist Retreat (TLRAR) residency subscribes to the concept of leisure as therapy for the Black creative and is committed to offering space and curated experiences conducive to their rejuvenation. Set in a park-like private residence, the property is nestled in the heart of Waverly, a historic Baltimore neighborhood. Each residency cycle, TLRAR will welcome guests by invitation only to a four-week stay of self-reflection and fellowship with like-minded individuals in search of a nurturing respite. Along with housing, meals and private workspaces, TLRAR will offer therapeutic services led by trained practitioners to support the physical and mental well-being of guests."

#tawnychatmon #bma #tlrar

✨In the news✨

I’m thrilled to have received my copy of The Kenyon Review today, featuring The Awakening/Covered on the cover of their 2023 Summer issue! Thank you @kenyonreview, so beautiful! 

For anyone that would like to purchase a copy for their collection, The Kenyon Review created a webpage and discount codes for friends and family (the link is in my profile)

About The Kenyon Review:
"The Kenyon Review, an international journal of literature, culture, and the arts is published in March, June, September, and December at Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio 43022. Since its founding in 1939, it has evolved from a distinguished literary magazine into a nonprofit arts organization."

Los Angeles!! 

Remnants/Bold Brilliance will be on view for curator Mashonda Tifrere’s summer exhibition titled 100 Days of Summer. 

“Curator Mashonda Tifrere presents her third annual summer exhibition Art Genesis: 100 Days of Summer, opening on July 26 and closing on August 5 in Los Angeles (3110 West Sunset Blvd Silver Lake). The exhibition showcases original works from eight standout, early and mid career artists: Arielle Austin, Akilah Watts, Jewel Ham, Lanise Howard, Tawny Chatmon, Victor Ubah, Natalie Lauren, and Ronnie Robinson.”

Remnants Statement:

What began as simple musings transformed into a broader understanding that all things have been handed down in some way or another. Moral and immoral. Noble and wicked. Battered and brand-new. Heirlooms, hand-me-downs, knowledge, traditions, habits, legacies, genetics, and lessons. Each is a remnant of the past, revealing itself in many ways in our present and future. 

In this series titled "Remnants," I have applied relics of my past painted works, cut into tiny pieces, to construct garments representing multiple significances. First, an honoring of our ancestors and those before us that passed down their cherished belongings and teachings as a means of survival. Second, an acknowledgment that we can break free of past beliefs, customs, and traumas that do not serve us. Last, how we must look to deconstruct systems of the past to assist us in reconstructing a brighter future.

@_artgenesis @mashondatifrere 

Remnants/Bold Brilliance, 2021/23, 24k gold leaf, paper, acrylic on archival pigment print, 24 x 20"

✨Limited edition prints now available in support of TLRAR✨

For anyone that has asked over the years, I now have a few limited edition prints available for sale through Art + Culture (@artandcultureny) in support of The Last Resort Artist Retreat. 

The sale of this print and others directly benefits The Last Resort Artist Retreat (@thelastresortartistretreat), founded by @derrickadamsny. "TLRAR is an artist's residency that subscribes to the concept of leisure as therapy for the Black creative and is committed to offering the space and curated experience conducive to their rejuvenation. Set in a park-like private residence, the property is nestled in the heart of Waverly, a historic Baltimore neighborhood. Each residency cycle, they will welcome guests by invitation-only to a four-week stay of self-reflection and fellowship with like-minded individuals in search of a nurturing respite."

Click the link in my bio to view and/or purchase one of the prints of "Let me go forward" (pictured above) while they are still available.

Photo details: 
Let me go forward, Archival pigment print on Hahnemuhle Photo Rag 308 gsm paper, 15, 2 APs, 2 PPs, 2022, 9.747 x 14.99 inches

I considered holding off on revealing this artwork until the opening of the upcoming exhibition where it will be on view ("There Within Lies the Gospel: Truth," at Galerie Myrtis opening Sept. 2. Announcement to follow). However, I know I've been sharing the process videos for months, and, today just seems like the perfect day. As we cheer on the unity of Black men and women in Montgomery, Alabama, I know for a fact that our ancestors are looking down and smiling BIG. This display of being "tired" highlights the accumulated grievances of the Black community in Alabama and EVERYWHERE. In other words… leave us alone & stop playin with us. 

This piece titled "Iconography/In honor of the sacred divinity that exists within us" depicts a young Black girl (my daughter) adorned in a gilded mosaic (tiny cut paper tiles) garment and robe draped around her shoulders, drawing inspiration from religious Byzantine mosaics. An iconographic representation of Harriet Tubman is at the heart of her attire, and the letter combination "AR" for her birth name Araminta Ross and "HT" for Harriet Tubman. This marks the completion of the third piece in this series and is my first completed attempt at crafting a "mosaic" portrayal of a person. As I continue this journey, you will begin to see more iconographic depictions of historical Black figures incorporated into the attire of my subjects. 

What it took to finally complete her is a story for another time. 

Oh, and you best believe Shirley Chisolm is one of the very next. As many have pointed out, her quote, "If they don't give you a seat at the table, bring a folding chair." has an all-new meaning right now. 

About Iconography:
Iconography is a new and ongoing body of work influenced by Byzantine icons & religious iconography. While in Venice during the Biennale, I stood again charmed by tilework, mosaics, and icons. An icon is a work typically of religious nature. These visual declarations were used to assist the observer in focusing on all things sacred and were viewed as literal prayers. My icons are not meant to be worshiped but regarded as important, precious, sacred, valuable, and an embodiment of my prayers.

#tawnychatmon

🎉🥳✨I’m deeply honored to announce that the Pretucci Foundation has acquired Iconography/A Hopeful Truth. Thank you, @pff_collection; I know that through this acquisition, this work will be viewed by many around the world!

"The PFF Collection of African American Art is a targeted initiative to bring focus to the full range of African-American visual creativity and its essential place in the history and discourse of American art.

An understanding of African-American art history is vital to a full understanding of American art history. The PFF collection offers continuing proof that African American art is integral to the rich tapestry of American creative tradition. Long overlooked, art of this caliber with its specific cultural voice is both essential and enlightening." - The Petrucci Family Foundation

(Shortened) Iconography formal statement:
Iconography is an evolving body of work influenced by Byzantine icons and religious iconography. While in Venice during the Biennale, I again stood charmed by the tilework, mosaics, and icons found across Italy.

An icon is a work typically religious in nature. These visual declarations were used to assist the observer in focusing on all things sacred and were viewed more as literal prayers than art. Believed to serve as conduits to the divine, each was meticulously crafted by an iconographer on a journey of prayer and meditation. As they created, their hands were believed to have been guided by the spirit of the most high. 

While my "icons" deviate from the traditional context of worship, like icons of the past, they nevertheless call on the viewer to recognize their significance, preciousness, sacred nature, and value as they embody my prayers for them and the world. And, reminiscent of the tesserae used to make Byzantine mosaics, the gilded paper remnants of my past works cut into tiny tiles take on new energy as they're carefully arranged, constructing works transcending the earthly, connecting to the heavens.

I am overjoyed to share the latest issue of Pigment International Magazine featuring my work on the cover. Inside, you will find a beautiful feature of my work, as well as an interview with @galeriemyrtis, a beautiful feature about collectors Vicki & Bruce Heyman & other incredible talents & fellow artist friends such as @blackboxpress, @m.scott_johnson, @arviesmithartist, @monica165, @larry_william21, @moreldoucet & more!

My deepest gratitude to @veelharrison, @patriciaandrewskeenan & the team at @pigmentintl for their dedication, care, and commitment to putting together such an important publication. Your labor of love & dedication to celebrating Black art & artistry is deeply appreciated, and I am honored to be a part.

If you'd like to grab a copy, please find the link to purchase in my profile.

I remain grateful for the amazing opportunities that come my way that allow me to share my work with the world. Thank you, Thank you, Thank you, Thank you!

re-sharing an interview that holds a special place in my heart. In 2021, I had the privilege of sitting down with @sincerely.jenee (an incredible columnist for @bostonglobe, founder of @abeautifulresistance + so much more) for a feature on @abeautifulresistance. The moment Jeneé came across my work a few years ago in Miami, she has since been a huge supporter of me and my work in so many ways. This conversation was one of the most comfortable, organic, free-flowing “interviews” I’ve had. I am so grateful for her support, existence & the beautiful work that she does! Cinematographer @snapsbykat was equally a joy and so easy to work with! 

If you are not familiar with @abeautifulresistance, I invite you to head over to their page & take a look at the amazing work they are doing & follow along while you’re there. And if you’re not familiar with @sincerely.jenee, please get to know her & the important work she does 🙏🏽

*sidenote: I wonder if we ever get over not liking hearing our own voices! lol

I'm thrilled to share that Deeply Embedded/God II is gracing the cover of Denene Millner's (@mybrownbaby) new book, One Blood & It's absolutely stunning! The artwork slightly differs from the original version as the women embedded in my subject's hair are meant to embody the women within the book & I adore the color pops that were added.

As some of my art friends may know, in the past, I've flip-flopped on the idea of licensing my works, preferring to keep them within the original context for which they were created, but when I was approached about my work being used for the cover of Denene's new book, alignment stepped in, and I said yes (I’m very happy that I did) 

"Denene Millner is a masterful weaver of words, characters, and worlds. ONE BLOOD is a beautiful, brilliant American epic that speaks to Black motherhood, female relationship, marriage, family, legacy, love and healing. It is simultaneously deeply intimate and grandly sweeping."--Tarana Burke, New York Times bestselling author of Unbound: My Story of Liberation and the Birth of the Me Too Movement

If you'd like to grab a copy, I've added the link in my profile & if for some reason you are not familiar with @mybrownbaby, please check her out along with her publishing company @denenemillnerbooks. She has published and written many very important books for Black children & families 🙏🏽

Ps. I think I’ll call this year my cover girl year! Because the covers are covering 🙌🏽

I am overjoyed to have a copy of Up.St.ART Annapolis (@upstartannapolis) featuring Remnants/Aunt Mattie's Beloved Frock (2021) on the cover in my hands. 

There are eight pages in the magazine featuring my work, accompanied by a beautifully written piece by Terese Schlachter that profoundly captures the meaning behind my work beautifully. 

The issue is not available online yet, but when it is, I will surely add the link to my link tree in my bio!

Thank you to the staff over at @upstartannapolis for such an absolutely beautiful and thoughtful feature!

Ps. The denim overalls/apron (that I painted in), which you can see in the photo of me featured in Up.St.ART magazine was made for me by my talented sister-friend @vibratinghigh1979 @mafiamoms_est2019! I’m happy we captured it in the beginning stages of me getting paint on it because it’s much more covered in paint now than it was in the photo.

📣📣📣
You are cordially invited to an enlightening discussion hosted by the Baltimore Museum of Art (BMA) titled “Risk-Taking Women in the Arts: Tawny Chatmon & Myrtis Bedolla.” This program draws inspiration from the exhibition “Making Her Mark: A History of Women Artists in Europe, 1400–1800,” which showcases the remarkable contributions of women in the visual arts of Europe through a diverse collection of over 200 works spanning various media and scales. This exhibition seeks to shed light on the often overlooked and multifaceted ways in which women have enriched the field of visual arts.

During the discussion, the co-panelists will speak about the bravery exhibited by women in the arts, explore the dynamic relationship between gallerists and the artists they represent & more!

This event will occur on Thursday, November 9th, from 6:00 to 8:30 p.m. at the BMA. Registration is required to participate in this free program. Please click the link in our bio to secure your spot.
Part 1.

Part 2. The last slide is also extremely important right now (always has been) 

Because I will be away, I have disabled the comments as I will be unable to respond. Thank you to those who have already reached out to me via email.

1/3 I don’t have a thought-out caption today. I think that maybe I just wanted to sprinkle a little joy, even if it’s fleeting. The three images I am sharing today are the final three works closing my series, The Redemption. Happy to finally finish the last remaining pieces.

I think I also wanted to tell you that I’m still here. I started my self-directed residences & research in December for my series Iconography, which has been planned since the beginning of 2023 & am also preparing for a few amazing exhibitions that I will announce soon.

But to be honest, I’m struggling to operate in this world, becoming more and more aware of how this world truly is (at its core), and, for anyone who is feeling the same, you’re not alone. I don’t say this in the sense that I don’t want to be here, but that I wonder how I’m walking the same planet as some of the evils that exist… Or maybe what I am trying to say is that I am changed, again and that 2023 (especially the final months) has greatly altered my perspective on the world, and humanity. All of this to say. None of what is happening is normal, and none of this is how it’s supposed to be, no matter how much they’ve tried to convince you that it is. 

Western values? Liberty, democracy, human rights, equality… where, when?

Pictured: Remnants/Now is the Time for Good, 2021/2023

2/3 Remnants/That Which is Planted, Shall Become the Harvest, 2021-2023

(The final 3 from this series)

3/3 Remnants/I Choose to Radiate Light Into the World 2021-2023

(The final 3 from this series)
